call_title: Machina Finance: eUTXO-Native P2P DEX on Ergo — Alison Robson (Ergo Meetup 2025)

topics.title: Introduction and Background on Ergo
topics.summary: Alison introduces himself and his involvement with major Ergo projects including Nautilus Wallet and Fleet SDK. He expresses gratitude for meeting the community in person.

topics.title: Machina DEX Architecture and eUTXO Design
topics.summary: Overview of Machina as a UTXO-native P2P decentralized exchange where each order is an individual contract. The design avoids emulating EVM contracts and uses grid orders instead of liquidity pools, with self-custodial asset control and no proxy contracts.

topics.title: Nautilus Batching Mechanism Implementation
topics.summary: Discussion of implementing batching directly in Nautilus wallet with slippage tolerance and transaction resignation capability. Users become their own batchers in this decentralized approach.

topics.title: Decentralized Architecture with Hermes Streaming
topics.summary: Explanation of the system's structural overview emphasizing true decentralization where application logic runs in the user's browser. Hermes provides real-time UTXO streaming from indexed nodes.

topics.title: Trading Strategies and Contract Composability
topics.summary: Description of two trading strategies: auto-compounding for profit maximization and cumulative strategy for conservative trading. All contracts are composable with other protocols like SigmaFi.

topics.title: Contract Optimization and Transaction Capacity
topics.summary: Technical details on contract optimization achieving 300 bytes for grid contracts and 16 bytes for single orders. This allows fitting 219 orders in a single 97kb transaction with potential for larger transactions through mining pools.

topics.title: No Protocol Fees Public Good Model
topics.summary: Decision to eliminate protocol-level fees to benefit ecosystem growth, making Machina a public good similar to SigmaUSD. This allows other applications to freely use Machina's liquidity.

topics.title: Hermes Tool and Mempool Awareness
topics.summary: Detailed explanation of Hermes as a mempool-aware UTXO streaming tool that enables transaction chaining. It simplifies mempool state tracking and enables real-time price tracking.

topics.title: Transaction Throughput Analysis
topics.summary: Technical analysis of transaction capacity showing 290 orders per transaction in worst case, with potential for 30,000 orders per block through chaining. Discussion of sub-blocks and comparison to other blockchains.

topics.title: Liquidity Strategy and Market Making
topics.summary: Discussion of liquidity building through arbitrage opportunities between Spectrum DEX and Machina. Users act as their own market makers with controlled risk exposure through grid ranges.

topics.title: Hermes as Fleet SDK Successor
topics.summary: Explanation of development philosophy creating reusable tools like Fleet SDK from Nautilus. Hermes follows this pattern and will replace GraphQL in Nautilus, addressing past implementation mistakes.

topics.title: Development Roadmap and Release Timeline
topics.summary: Project timeline with contracts under review, Hermes completion by end of year, Machina SDK by Q1, and full beta on Mainnet by Q2. SDK will enable community development of arbitrage bots before UI release.

topics.title: Block Size Calculations and Scalability
topics.summary: Detailed calculations showing 3,750 orders per block capacity with current parameters. Discussion of miner voting for larger block sizes and comparison to other blockchain throughput capabilities.

topics.title: Transaction Fees and WebSocket Implementation
topics.summary: Discussion of transaction baseline fees and implementation details. Hermes will use WebSockets for real-time streaming, reducing explorer API spam and maintenance costs while providing better real-time capabilities.

topics.title: Best Case Transaction Capacity
topics.summary: Final calculations showing best case scenario of 16,000 transactions per block with smallest order sizes, demonstrating the maximum theoretical throughput of the system.
